bill_title: provide for collection of data and information concerning electronic commerce.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to provide for collection of data and information concerning electronic commerce. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Revenue; (2) "Electronic commerce," any business to consumer sale conducted through the Internet that is subject to taxation pursuant to chapter 10-45, 10-46, or 10-52. Electronic commerce includes the sale of tangible and intangible goods and services; (3) "Electronic commerce vendor," any person engaged in business to consumer sales of goods or services through an Internet web site. Section 2. The department shall collect primary and supplementary data to provide the South Dakota Legislature with an accurate rendering of the level of electronic commerce activity within the state. The primary data set shall include: (1) The number of electronic commerce venders domiciled within the state; (2) The gross retail sales of electronic commerce vendors domiciled within the state; (3) An estimate of the number of in-state electronic commerce transactions conducted by persons within the state boundaries based on accepted standards of scientific sampling; (4) An estimate of the number of out-of-state electronic commerce transactions conducted by persons within the state boundaries based on accepted standards of scientific sampling; (5) An estimate of the total value of electronic commerce transactions conducted by persons within state boundaries during a calendar year; and (6) A reliable estimate of the use tax revenue that is uncollected due to out-of-state electronic commerce. Section 3. The department shall supplement the primary data with information supplied by the South Dakota Business Research Bureau and United States Department of Commerce; the United States Census Bureau, the United States Small Business Administration, and any other federal agency collecting electronic commerce data. The department may use information gathered from any private, academic, and other nongovernmental entities provided that the source and methodology is stated within the text of the report and the information is not speculative in nature or based on unscientific methods. Section 4. The department shall include an analysis of the financial impact increased sales and use tax collection requirements would have on instate companies engaged in electronic commerce. Section 5. The department shall submit the data and information required by this Act to the Legislature by the fifteenth day of January each year. Section 6. This Act is repealed on January 16, 2005.
